qas.question: How severe are Florida disenfranchisement laws

answers.text: Florida is among the three states with the most severe felony disenfranchisement laws.

qas.question: What doe s the law require for criminals

answers.text: felons to have completed sentencing, parole and/or probation, and then seven years later, to apply individually for restoration of voting privileges

qas.question: Who does this law effect most

answers.text: this law has disproportionate effects for minorities
one in ten Floridians – and nearly one in four African-American Floridians – are shut out of the polls because of felony convictions

qas.question: What criminals are forced to have incomplete sentencing?
Felons have to wait eight years to restore which privilege?
How many Mexicans are shut out of the polls?
What type of conviction still allows people to vote?

context: <a0_0>Florida is among the three states with the most severe felony disenfranchisement laws.<a0_0/> Florida requires <a1_0><b4_0>felons<b4_0/> to have completed sentencing, parole and/or probation, and then seven years later, to apply individually for restoration of <b5_0>voting privileges<b5_0/><a1_0/>. As in other aspects of the criminal justice system, <a2_0>this law has disproportionate effects for minorities<a2_0/>. As a result, according to Brent Staples, based on data from The Sentencing Project, the effect of Florida's law is such that in 2014 "[m]ore than <a3_0>one in ten Floridians – and <b6_0>nearly one in four<b6_0/> African-American Floridians – are shut out of the polls because of <b7_0>felony<b7_0/> convictions<a3_0/>."
